revisions.rev:
{{Infobox U.S. County | county = Jefferson County | state = Kentucky | seal = 200px-Louisville Kentucky seal.png | founded year = 1780 | founded date = | seat wl = Louisville | area_total_sq_mi = 398.58 | area_total_km2 = | area_land_sq_mi = 385.09 | area_land_km2 = | area_water_sq_mi = 13.49 | area_water_km2 = | area percentage = 3.38% | census estimate yr = 2010 | pop = 741,096 | density_sq_mi = 1871 | density_km2 = | time zone = Eastern | UTC offset = -5 | DST offset = -4 | footnotes = | web = www.louisvilleky.gov | named for = [[Thomas Jefferson]], [[President of the United States]] (1801â1809) | ex image = Jefferson County KY Courthouse 2.jpg | ex image cap = [[Louisville Metro Hall|Jefferson County Courthouse]] in Louisville }} '''Jefferson County''' is a [[County (USA)|county]] located in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Kentucky]]. It is the most populous county in Kentucky and is more than twice as populous as the second most populous, [[Fayette County, Kentucky|Fayette]]. It was formed in 1780. The population was 741,096 in the 2010 Census. Jefferson County is the most populous county in the [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville/Jefferson County]], KYâ[[Indiana|IN]] [[Louisville-Jefferson County, KY-IN Metropolitan Statistical Area|Metropolitan Statistical Area]]. ==History== {{See also|History of Louisville, Kentucky}} [[Image:Jefferson county marker.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Historic marker at the Jefferson County Courthouse]] Jefferson County was organized in 1780 and one of the first three counties formed out of the original [[Kentucky County, Virginia|Kentucky County]], which was still part of [[Virginia]] at the time (the other two being [[Fayette County, Kentucky|Fayette]] and [[Lincoln County, Kentucky|Lincoln]]). The county is named for [[Thomas Jefferson]], who was governor of [[Virginia]] at the time. The last major American Indian raid in present day Jefferson County was the [[Chenoweth Massacre]] on July 17, 1789. In 2003, its government merged with that of its largest city and county seat, [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]], forming a new entity, the ''Louisville-Jefferson County Metro Government'' (the official long form) or simply ''Louisville Metro'' (the official short form). Prior to this merger, the head of local government was the [[Jefferson County Judge/Executive|County Judge/Executive]], a post that still exists but now has few powers. The current incumbent is [[Ken Herndon]]. Local government is effectively now led by the [[Mayor of Louisville Metro]], [[Greg Fischer]]. ==Geography== According to the 2000 census, the county has a total area of {{convert|398.58|sqmi}}, of which {{convert|385.09|sqmi}} (or 96.62%) is land and {{convert|13.49|sqmi}} (or 3.38%) is water.{{cite web |url=http://www.census.gov/tiger/tms/gazetteer/county2k.txt |title=Census 2000 U.S. Gazetteer Files: Counties |publisher=United States Census |accessdate=2011-02-13 }} The [[Ohio River]] forms its northern boundary with the state of [[Indiana]]. The highest point is South Park Hill, elevation {{convert|902|ft|m}}, located in the southern part of the county.{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} The lowest point is {{convert|383|ft|m}} along the Ohio River just north of [[West Point, Kentucky]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} ===Adjacent counties=== *[[Bullitt County, Kentucky|Bullitt County]] (south) *[[Shelby County, Kentucky|Shelby County]] (east) *[[Oldham County, Kentucky|Oldham County]] (northeast) *[[Spencer County, Kentucky|Spencer County]] (southeast) *[[Hardin County, Kentucky|Hardin County]] (southwest) *[[Clark County, Indiana]] (north, across the [[Ohio River]]) *[[Harrison County, Indiana]] (west, across the Ohio River) *[[Floyd County, Indiana]] (northwest, across the Ohio River) {{See also|List of counties bordering eight or more counties#Eight counties|l1=List of counties bordering eight counties}} ==Demographics== {{USCensusPop | 1790= 4765 | 1800= 8754 | 1810= 13399 | 1820= 20768 | 1830= 23979 | 1840= 36346 | 1850= 59831 | 1860= 89404 | 1870= 118953 | 1880= 146010 | 1890= 188598 | 1900= 232549 | 1910= 262920 | 1920= 286369 | 1930= 355350 | 1940= 385392 | 1950= 484615 | 1960= 610947 | 1970= 695055 | 1980= 685004 | 1990= 664937 | 2000= 693604 | 2010= 741096 | estimate= | estyear= | estref= | footnote= }} As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 693,604 people, 287,012 households, and 183,113 families residing in the county. The [[population density]] was {{convert|1801|/sqmi|/km2}}. There were 305,835 housing units at an average density of {{convert|794|/sqmi|/km2}}. The racial makeup of the county was 77.38% [[Race (United States Census)|White]], 18.88% [[Race (United States Census)|Black]] or [[Race (United States Census)|African American]], 0.22% [[Race (United States Census)|Native American]], 1.39% [[Race (United States Census)|Asian]], 0.04% [[Race (United States Census)|Pacific Islander]], 0.68% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 1.42% from two or more races. 1.78% of the population were [[Hispanics in the United States|Hispanic]] or [[Race (United States Census)|Latino]] of any race. There were 287,012 households out of which 29.60% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 45.20% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 14.70% had a female householder with no husband present, and 36.20% were non-families. 30.50% of all households were made up of individuals and 10.30% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.37 and the average family size was 2.97. In the county the population was spread out with 24.30% under the age of 18, 8.90% from 18 to 24, 30.40% from 25 to 44, 22.80% from 45 to 64, and 13.50% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 37 years. For every 100 females there were 91.60 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 87.60 males. The median income for a household in the county was $43,789 (2005), and the median income for a family was $49,161. Males had a median income of $36,484 versus $26,255 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the county was $22,352. About 9.50% of families and 12.40% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 18.10% of those under age 18 and 8.80% of those age 65 or over. ==Cities, towns and census-designated places== [[File:Jefferson County KY places.svg|thumb|400px|left]] ''NOTE:'' Since the formation of ''Louisville Metro'' on January 6, 2003, residents of the cities below also became citizens of the newly expanded Metro, but none of the incorporated places have dissolved in the process. The functions formerly served by the county government for the town were assumed by Louisville Metro. However, the former City of Louisville was effectively absorbed into the new city-county government.{{Clear}} {| width="92%" class="wikitable" | |- | width="25%" align="left" style="vertical-align: top; " | *[[Rolling Hills, Kentucky|Rolling Hills]] *[[Seneca Gardens, Kentucky|Seneca Gardens]] *[[Shively, Kentucky|Shively]] *[[South Park View, Kentucky|South Park View]] *[[Spring Mill, Kentucky|Spring Mill]] *[[Spring Valley, Kentucky|Spring Valley]] *[[Springlee, Kentucky|Springlee]] *[[St. Dennis, Louisville|St. Dennis]] â  *[[St. Matthews, Kentucky|St. Matthews]] *[[St. Regis Park, Kentucky|St. Regis Park]] *[[Strathmoor Manor, Kentucky|Strathmoor Manor]] *[[Strathmoor Village, Kentucky|Strathmoor Village]] *[[Sycamore, Kentucky|Sycamore]] *[[Ten Broeck, Kentucky|Ten Broeck]] *[[Thornhill, Kentucky|Thornhill]] *[[Valley Station, Louisville|Valley Station]] â  *[[Watterson Park, Kentucky|Watterson Park]] *[[Wellington, Kentucky|Wellington]] *[[West Buechel, Kentucky|West Buechel]] *[[Westwood, Jefferson County, Kentucky|Westwood]] *[[Whipps Millgate, Kentucky|Whipps Millgate]] *[[Wildwood, Kentucky|Wildwood]] *[[Windy Hills, Kentucky|Windy Hills]] *[[Woodland Hills, Kentucky|Woodland Hills]] *[[Woodlawn Park, Kentucky|Woodlawn Park]] *[[Worthington Hills, Kentucky|Worthington Hills]] |} :â  formerly a [[Census-designated Place]] in the county, however, in 2003, these places became neighborhoods within the city limits of ''Louisville Metro''.
